title: Jehoash's Deliverance and Reign
shortSummary: This chapter recounts the dramatic preservation and coronation of Jehoash, the rightful heir to the throne of Judah, who was hidden from Athaliah’s murderous purge. Under the guidance of the priest Jehoiada, Jehoash is anointed king, Athaliah is executed, and the people renew their covenant with the Lord, restoring true worship.
timeline: c. 840 BC - Period of the Divided Kingdom, during the reign of Athaliah in Judah

keyCharacters.name: Athaliah
keyCharacters.description: Mother of Ahaziah who seized power by killing the royal heirs, reigning as queen and opposing the Davidic line.

keyCharacters.name: Jehoash (Joash)
keyCharacters.description: Son of Ahaziah, hidden and preserved by Jehosheba, later anointed king to restore the Davidic dynasty.

keyCharacters.name: Jehosheba
keyCharacters.description: Daughter of King Joram and sister of Ahaziah, who courageously hid Jehoash to protect him from Athaliah’s massacre.

keyCharacters.name: Jehoiada
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who orchestrated the protection and coronation of Jehoash, leading a covenant renewal and purging Baal worship.

definitions.definition: The descendants or offspring of the royal family, specifically the heirs to the throne.
The temple in Jerusalem, the central place of worship for Israel and Judah.
Military leaders responsible for groups of one hundred soldiers, used here to organize the guard for Jehoash’s protection.
A solemn agreement between God and His people involving commitments and promises.

outline.heading: Athaliah’s Usurpation and Jehoash’s Preservation
outline.description: Athaliah kills all royal heirs to secure her throne, but Jehosheba secretly hides Jehoash in the temple for six years, preserving the Davidic line.

outline.heading: Preparation for Jehoash’s Coronation
outline.description: Jehoiada organizes the military leaders and temple guards to protect Jehoash, arming them with David’s spears and shields, ensuring the king’s safety during the coronation.

outline.heading: Jehoash Crowned King and Athaliah’s Execution
outline.description: Jehoash is publicly anointed and proclaimed king; Athaliah is exposed, arrested, and executed outside the temple to maintain its sanctity.

outline.heading: Renewal of Covenant and Purging of Baal Worship
outline.description: Jehoiada leads the people in a covenant renewal with the Lord, destroys Baal’s temple and altars, and reestablishes true worship under the new king.

outline.heading: Jehoash’s Reign Begins
outline.description: The chapter closes with the official beginning of Jehoash’s reign at the age of seven, marking a new era for Judah.

application: Trust God’s providence to preserve His promises even in times of great danger and opposition.
Be courageous in protecting and promoting godly leadership and truth within your sphere of influence.
Commit to covenant faithfulness with God, renewing your dedication to Him regularly.
Reject idolatry and false worship, seeking to honor God in all aspects of life.

keyVerses.text: But Jehosheba, the daughter of king Joram, sister of Ahaziah, took Joash the son of Ahaziah, and stole him from among the king's sons which were slain; and they hid him, even him and his nurse, in the bedchamber from Athaliah, so that he was not slain.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s providential preservation of the rightful heir, demonstrating His faithfulness to His covenant promises.

keyVerses.text: And he brought forth the king's son, and put the crown upon him, and gave him the testimony; and they made him king, and anointed him; and they clapped their hands, and said, God save the king.
keyVerses.significance: The public anointing of Jehoash signifies the restoration of God’s chosen dynasty and the rejection of usurped power.

keyVerses.text: And Jehoiada made a covenant between the LORD and the king and the people, that they should be the LORD'S people; between the king also and the people.
keyVerses.significance: This covenant renewal underscores the importance of communal commitment to God as the foundation for national and spiritual restoration.
